Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2014 01:21PM geekyknitter wrote: For me, it was easiest to let remarks like that go.  Like others have mentioned, it could be that she had really good intentions and was trying to say the right thing or it could be that she needs to be in denial that something like this can happen to someone this close to her because, by extension, that means it can happen to her as well.  Either way, unless you really know how she'll take it, bringing it up is likely to cause you more stress that you don't need. I also find I prefer sometimes to kind of retreat into myself when I'm dealing with something difficult and I try to balance that with not isolating myself.  I think sometimes it's healthy to pull back a little and it definitely helps to avoid those awkward conversations.  I have found that trying to find ways to be around people where there is some kind of organized activity going on helps.  That way, the focus is on what we are DOING and I feel less alone or self-conscious.  I also knit and bringing a project with me can be a good distraction.  Above all, though, I find if I can make myself get outdoors and spend some time even just walking by myself, I feel so much better than if I give in to my instinct to hole up in my house. I'm sure you'll find what works best for you.  As far as the kids go, I think it is important that they not feel too isolated.  I remember being the "kid from the cancer family" and mostly, I just wanted to feel normal and doing "normal" things that I usually did helped with that.  If you don't feel up to it, you might consider seeing if someone else can take them to the things they would normally go to.  I also felt better when I knew what was going on, but that can depend a lot on the age of the kids.  There are groups now for kids with family members with cancer that might help them also find friends that will understand what they are going through.
Posts.Title: dealing w people cathycteach geekyknitter

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2014 11:17AM geekyknitter wrote: Hugs! People are "weird" about cancer.  I learned this pretty quickly growing up as a sibling of someone with cancer and with many relatives with cancer.  Perfectly normal, kind, sane people often act in completely bizarre ways when you or someone you are close to get a cancer diagnosis.  You really can't predict who will step up and become your biggest support (and often it's someone you never would have thought you'd be close to!) and who simply won't be able to handle it. The way I've come to handle it is by maybe being a little bit selfish in some ways.  When it happens, I focus my energy on the people who are there and can be there and I prioritize spending time with them because I need that support.  Those who simply aren't comfortable or can't really grasp what I'm going through...I let them drift off as they need to or simply prioritize time with them lower for now.  I try to understand that their reaction to what's going on usually is a lot more about where they are.  Maybe the diagnosis has sparked fear in them.  Maybe they just don't know how to respond and are doing their best.  There are all kinds of reasons people say or do stupid or hurtful things when cancer is involved and almost all of them have to do with how that person handles these things and nothing at all to do with the patient or their family or how that person feels about them. After things have calmed down, some of those relationships have come back and some haven't.  Sometimes they evolve into a different kind of friendship and the friendships that I gained during the "crisis" time have grown in other directions.  I even have some friends who seem to only want to be there when there is a crisis.  I find if I'm just open to letting those things change as they will, it's a lot easier. Sorry for droning on!  You also might want to look into local support groups where you could make new friends who would better understand exactly what you're going through.  Your bf may also benefit from a group where he could talk with other family and partners of people since he has a lot to adjust to and may also feel like his current friends might not understand. Again, big hugs to you!
Posts.Title: dealing w people cathycteach geekyknitter

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2014 03:46PM geekyknitter wrote: Waiting...just sucks.  No two ways about it.  It sucks even more when you think you have a clear direction and are ready to move forward and then...nope, more waiting. I'll have my fingers crossed that you'll get your results quickly AND be able to move on to that lumpectomy as scheduled.  Feel free to vent away!  :)

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2014 07:18PM geekyknitter wrote: I'm kind of wondering why it was an "all or nothing" choice as well?  It seems like they should be able to biopsy a couple of the bigger ones on each side rather than either turning you into a porcupine or waiting.  :/ I'm not a good waiting person either, so I might have gone the pincushion route, but I can definitely understand not wanting to do that for a bunch of fibroadenomas.  I'm guessing they could tell pretty definitively from imaging that this is what they were, which is why you were given the option to wait at all.  (Nice, rounded shape with smooth margins, etc.)
Posts.Title: Multiple lumps in both breasts cs79 MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2014 07:27AM geekyknitter wrote: There is not some limited quantity of admiration to go around, just as there isn't some limited quantity of bad luck to go around. AJ's situation...sucks.  Maybe it sucks less than someone else's and it likely does, but it still sucks.  I can admire her for how she's handled her sucky situation without in any way detracting from the amount I admire women somehow dealing with even more sucky situations.  It's not like someone saying she is brave somehow means that anyone else is less brave.  It's not a competition and there are no winners when it comes to surgeries and risks for cancer.  If there were, I'm betting the winner of the "cancer trophy" would be more than happy to trade it in exchange for being healthy and not having to go through cancer treatment. I also think that having high profile celebrities dealing with BC and BC risk publicly does help others.  Years ago, when my OB/GYN casually brought up BRCA testing, I didn't know much about it and opted not to test.  Hearing about AJ's testing and surgery was one of several things that prompted me to research genetic testing more and that researching eventually led me to where I am now, waiting on my own genetic testing results.  All this and I'm not even a huge AJ fan.  Who knows how many other people became more informed about genetic testing for cancer risk from hearing about her surgeries?  I know my primary care doctor was even more aware of BRCA testing because of it...and that's a medical professional. And yeah...I have no idea who Ranic is, but then I'm not much up on pop culture.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2014 07:54AM geekyknitter wrote: That would have irritated me to no end as well.  Sorry you had to deal with that on top of everything else!  :P
Posts.Title: Angelina Jolie to have additional cancer preventing surgery Jelson Shellshine

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2014 02:18PM geekyknitter wrote: You're definitely not alone! I also come from a family where BC was rampant.  It's hard for this process not to dig up all those memories, even when the biopsy comes back benign.  Don't be hard on yourself for having a tough time with this!  I had my first lump and biopsy this year, which happily turned out to be a benign adema, but the entire process through me for a loop and suddenly, it felt like BC wasn't just something that happened to my older relatives, but something that could happen to ME.  It's as if going through all that suddenly made it real to me in a way even the passing of family members hadn't been, if that makes sense. Good luck on your upcoming biopsy and here's hoping they have benign results for you...and quickly!  In the meantime, feel free to vent and know you definitely are not alone.  :)
Posts.Title: Wondering if I'm alone on this journey? Nona32 NorthwindsGS

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2014 11:12AM geekyknitter wrote: It's not uncommon for a radiologist to want more views or a different kind of view with another form of imaging.  Often, it just means that they couldn't see real well into one breast and want a better look. Try not to worry until the doctors tell you there is something to worry about, as hard as that seems.  I myself just went through a diagnostic mammogram, with a call back for more views, followed by a breast MRI, followed by an ultrasound, followed by a biopsy... all for what turned out to be a small, completely benign fibroadenoma. When you have a family history of breast cancer, they like to be absolutely certain that there's nothing amiss, which is a good thing. Here's hoping for your appointment to get scheduled quickly and for you to get benign results, and quickly!  :)

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2014 05:49PM geekyknitter wrote: It's not uncommon to get called back for additional views.  I had a diagnostic mammogram this winter and had to have additional views taken because my breasts are dense and hard to image.  From the report, it doesn't sound like they expect to find anything suspicious, but that they want to be thorough and make sure that they've gotten clear views into the breast. I know it's really tough not to worry, particularly when you have a family history of breast cancer.  Waiting can be really tough, but here's hoping it goes quickly and you get benign results just as quickly!  :)

Posts.Title: 6 month follow up mammo tomorrow Petitegal127 Petitegal127

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2014 06:59PM geekyknitter wrote: Hugs...I'm in the waiting room with you!  Results will come.  It sounds like you're doing everything you can to get more information and I think it's a good thing that your doctor is sending you to a breast surgeon.  Often there are benign conditions that require someone who specializes in breasts to keep an eye on them.  Also, they very often will want a younger woman with dense breasts and benign cysts to be checked out and periodically watched over by a person who knows breasts inside and out, just to be sure. If it were me, I'd spend as much time as possible with the horses.  Their company is often the best!  :)  For me, since I don't have any horses, it's my horse of a dog.  ;)
Posts.Title: Help with results...so confused lilrebel MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2014 05:26PM geekyknitter wrote: Hugs, Genny.  I'm sorry you got this news while your husband is away, but at least you have the dogs, right?  Hugging my own dog is probably my best therapy.  :) One thought came to my mind.  Only you know your husband, but mine is the type that always feels better knowing.  He'd rather have bad news than no news and it's likely he's been worried and anxiously waiting the results, too.  Again, only you know how his mind operates, but mine would feel better getting the news even if he wasn't there and at least being able to try to comfort me over the phone.  Either way, he's likely to worry about you until he's home, but for some worrying with the unknown is tougher. I hope they get back to you quickly with some further information on what's happening next and in the meantime, hopefully the dogs will give you lots of kisses and love.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 09:23PM geekyknitter wrote: I believe there is a link on here that helps explain some of these terms.  Basically, it means that there is a mass that is visible on ultrasound and is solid, so it is not a fluid filled cyst.  In all likelihood, they will want a biopsy of it to know for sure.  Does the report also have a BIRADS scoring on it?  This might be more helpful. Big hugs to you.  From what you've posted here, this does not absolutely mean you have cancer.  80% of suspicious lumps turn out benign, but only a biopsy can tell for sure.  Have you spoken with your doctor yet as far as next steps?
Posts.Title: Terrified!!! :'( Terri001 jbdayton

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2014 07:05AM geekyknitter wrote: Swastika - Do you think you might be able to change your username?  It may be a little offensive to some of our Jewish board members.  (I know I am trying very hard myself, as a Jewish woman, NOT to judge you by it.) About your issues... It could very well be something simple like a benign cyst, which would fit well with your symptoms, but as others have said, only a doctor will be able to diagnose you for sure.  If it is a cyst, they can even remove fluid from it to give you some relief of the pain you are experiencing with your cycles.  Cysts are very common and don't increase your risk of cancer.  There are other completely benign possibilities, but any time you see a change in your body, it's a good idea to bring it up with your doctor rather than waiting years. Good luck with your doctor appointment and I hope everything goes well!  :)

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2014 08:19AM geekyknitter wrote: It's pretty common for fibrocystic breasts to become more inflamed and painful leading up to menopause.  It's very likely, as others have pointed out, that you always had fibrocystic breasts, but never had extensive imaging done before that they would show up on until now.  Even IF you did develop fibrocystic breasts later on, it wouldn't be a red flag for anything, although they definitely CAN be painful.  Mine are and grow moreso each year, but they're otherwise harmless.
Posts.Title: A few B9 conditions alicki alicki

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2014 11:54AM geekyknitter wrote: If you have concerns about your lifetime risk for cancer, a genetic counselor might be a great place to begin.  They can start by looking at your lifestyle and family history and advise you of your actual risk, which may be a lot different than what you are thinking it is. I grew up in a family full of breast and ovarian cancers and was surprised at how low my risk even was, when you run everything through a computer model.  It still was high enough that we are going through genetic testing to get more information, but if I test negative, it isn't high enough to suggest surgeries or anything further. When you are going through the process of diagnosing a breast condition, it is scary and it seems like breast cancer is all around you and EVERYONE is getting it.  It's also scary thinking about growing older and having screenings regularly.  However, surgery has its own risks and it's important to have all the information to weight those risks against your realistic cancer risk.  That is where a genetic counselor can be a big help. Big hugs to you and I hope everything goes well for you and you're back to focusing on life, rather than breasts!  :)

Posts.Title: Thank you all for being here Ram2645 SlowDeepBreaths

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2014 01:55PM geekyknitter wrote: I'm not a doctor and it sounds like you've looked into a lot of the other reasons lymph nodes can enlarge.  It still could definitely be something else, but I hear your frustration in that you're still having the symptoms and no answers as to what it is. I have dense breasts and for me, ultrasound and breast MRI's are far more useful.  Breast MRI's can be tough to get in some cases because the facilities are limited and they do often generate false positives.  An ultrasound can really help them get a look at your lymph nodes, see if they have fluid in them or something solid, and assist with a biopsy if needed.  I will also say that my axillary lymph node, when they measured it at my US, was pretty big, but they said it was perfectly normal.  Bottom line, it sounds like you need the pros to take a look rather than have us guess and an ultrasound sounds like a good next step.  :) Whatever it is, I hope you get answers soon!
Posts.Title: Swollen lymph nodes under arm since last summer FarmingWife Tomboy

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2014 12:05PM geekyknitter wrote: Just responding...yes my lymph node, big as it was, was normal.  They didn't even biopsy it. Good luck on your ultrasound and I'll keep my fingers crossed for good news quickly!  :)
Posts.Title: Swollen lymph nodes under arm since last summer FarmingWife Tomboy

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2014 12:27PM geekyknitter wrote: Hugs!  I'm waiting on my own BRCA test results and it is nerve wracking.  Depending on the lab you test with, you may have a couple of months to wait for results. One thing that's helped me is keeping in mind how RARE BRCA mutations really are.  Even among breast cancer patients, they only account for something like 10-20% of all breast cancers.  Then, let's say you do have a BRCA mutation in your family (you don't say if anyone else has been tested), that STILL does not mean you have one.  Even if one of your parents has a BRCA mutation, you still would only have a 50-50 chance of having inherited it.  So...the odds are strongly in your favor to NOT have a BRCA mutation.  Worst case, if you do test positive, you will have time to consider all your options and some women only opt for increased screenings, particularly while they are still trying to have children and, even with a BRCA mutation, your children would only have a 50-50 chance of inheriting that mutation AND treatment and prevention options would have many years to evolve before they were of the age to be tested. I know it's very tough, but try not to go down the worst case road until you get to it.  The waiting can be pretty tough.  Also check out the FORCE (facing our risk) website.  They have a forum specifically for younger women who test positive for BRCA and you may be able to find some more support there as well.
Posts.Title: Getting BRCA testing tomorrow and I'm nervous Bad_At_Usernames Stunned_at_33

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2014 05:51PM geekyknitter wrote: Yep...that must have been my confusion, but I did know that, statistically, BRCA mutations are pretty rare as are cancers related to them.  It's a comforting thought when I'm waiting for test results that seem to take so long. I have a son and a daughter and I try to concentrate on the fact that treatment and early prevention have come SO far just during my lifetime (I'm 36) that I'm sure I can't imagine where they will be when my children are old enough to test.  So, even if I end up having a mutation and they have that 50/50 chance of inheriting it (all of which is doubtful), it's likely they'll have many more options than I even do now. Hang in there and best wishes for a negative result!
Posts.Title: Getting BRCA testing tomorrow and I'm nervous Bad_At_Usernames Stunned_at_33

That being said, getting scanned did find a small, unrelated mass that I'm getting a biopsy on this week (the radiologist is pretty sure it's benign), so I don't think screening is ever a waste of time.  :)

I know waiting is always hard, but it sounds very likely that you have nothing to worry about.

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2014 04:55PM geekyknitter wrote: I recently had a biopsy myself (benign, thank goodness!  Most of them are, btw), and my primary care doctor insisted that I have it done at the same imaging center that found the lump in the first place.  They were all set up to do biopsies and since the techs there had already found my lump, it was easy enough for them to find it again so they radiologist could do the biopsy.  Her reasoning for sticking with there was that then all the reports were in the same place and were looked at by the same team of radiologists. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2014 02:25PM geekyknitter wrote: I had a core needle biopsy as well.  I think it depends a lot on where your lump is and how hard it is for them to get a sample, but I got off pretty easy!  I had almost no bruising and really wasn't sore much after that day.  I think I took tylenol twice.  Now, that being said, I think my lump was closer to the surface and they had an easy time getting samples.  I could have camped the weekend after easy and it really would have been a nice way to relax after.  :) Fingers crossed that yours is as easy as mine!

Posts.Title: Skin Lesion in breast Sincs MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2014 04:30PM geekyknitter wrote: Hugs to you! Most cysts are benign and you actually may find some relief from the pain after the biopsy since it will remove some of the fluid that causes pressure.  As others have said, dense, fibrocystic breasts are very common and healthy. When it comes to genetic testing, it's never a bad idea to talk with a genetic counselor, but it's not likely that your insurance is going to cover genetic testing unless you have very close family relatives who have either tested positive for a mutation or you have enough close family members with breast cancer to suggest a mutation.  Very few genetic mutations associated with increased risk of breast cancer are also connected with gastric or esophogeal cancer.  I had a difficult time getting my genetic testing covered and needed a genetic counselor to talk to my insurance company on my behalf to get it covered.  (The breast and ovarian cancer is all on my father's side of the family and he is an only child and none of those women are alive now.) I can definitely relate to your anxiety, though, having had parents with different cancers.  A genetic counselor may be able to help you feel more comfortable with your situation or help you find the appropriate genetic testing and twist the insurance company's arm to cover it. Try not to worry and avoid Dr. Google.  Here's hoping for an easy biospy, a relief of your pain, AND benign results quickly!  :)
Posts.Title: Unknown maternal family history betsee betsee

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2014 09:04PM geekyknitter wrote: It all depends.  I've had pain and swelling in one breast and not the other.  Imaging should be able to tell the difference between a simple cyst and something else.  There are just so many benign breast conditions along with the cancerous ones that it can be hard to tell just from a list of symptoms exactly what is going on. In any case, I don't think getting some imaging done would be a waste of anyone's time, yours or the tech's.  Even if they don't find anything, depending on your age, it might be good to have a baseline anyway and it might help alleviate your worries.  :)
Posts.Title: Swelling, pain and firmness in one breast Beachgirl2 Kicks

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2014 09:05PM geekyknitter wrote: As far as caffeine intake, I think it again depends on a lot of other factors.  I was drinking a LOT of diet soda, so I cut that back a ton and went down to 1 cup of coffee a day and that seemed to help.  Your mileage may vary, but you could always try decreasing your intake a little and see if it helps.  I've also read about women taking evening primrose to help with breast pain.
Posts.Title: Swelling, pain and firmness in one breast Beachgirl2 Kicks

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2014 01:01PM geekyknitter wrote: My biopsy left only a tiny "nick," not a large scar.  They generally only take a very small amount of tissue and I had a core biopsy, which means a larger needle than a fine needle aspiration.  While it is true that a biopsy can cause a radial scar, that is pretty rare. An MRI is just another form of imaging.  My lump was found by MRI and then they looked at it again with ultrasound.  The problem is that imaging just shows us that something is there, not what it is.  It's pretty much assured that the docs would still want to do a biopsy after an MRI AND breast MRI's are very expensive AND doing one would delay getting the final results that a biopsy CAN give...so, I think a biopsy is what is going to give you the most definitive results the quickest.  If they do aspirate the cyst, they may be able to "see" behind it easier.  When I had my biopsy, they did a couple of quick images after to make sure the marker they left was properly placed. Crossing my fingers for benign results for you, and quickly!  :)
Posts.Title: Unknown maternal family history betsee betsee

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2014 07:30PM geekyknitter wrote: I'm another woman with dense, fibrocystic breasts.  I had a diagnostic mammogram in December, which showed nothing.  Then, they did a breast MRI as part of the process of getting tested for BRCA and it showed a small lump which also showed up on ultrasound.  Happily, it was biopsied and just a fibroadema, but yes, it can be a lot harder to see into dense breasts on a mammogram. I also have painful, fibrocystic breasts.  The pain can be pretty bad and I was nervous about it until I learned just how common it really is.  Cutting back on caffeine seems to have helped give me some relief. I hope you get results quickly as well as some relief from the pain.  On the bright side, breast MRI's and ultrasounds were SO much less uncomfortable for me than mammograms!
Posts.Title: Fibercystic Breast tissue-Left breast always causing me trouble. CCrill CCrill

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2014 01:44PM geekyknitter wrote: Waiting SUCKS.  There really is no way around it...it just sucks because you're in this awkward period of everything being on hold. I have to agree that finding things to distract yourself with is very helpful.  It also helped for me to give myself permission to have a set time period to just dwell on it all and let my emotions run wild.  It might not work for everyone, but for me, it helped me get a lot of it out and then be able to refocus a little bit better after. About the guilt...I think I understand.  When I was waiting on my benign results, I felt guilty for being so emotional and so worried when others had it so much worse, but the fact is that telling myself that didn't make my own fear and anxiety any better.  I had to kind of step back and be a little kinder to myself and accept that while others DO have it much worse, this was hard for me and that was ok.  My emotions through all this didn't mean that I was minimizing what others go through and it didn't mean that it wasn't right for me to feel the way I was feeling.  Feelings just are and they rarely listen to logic and can't really just be rationalized away. You'll get through this.  It sucks and it's hard, but you'll get through it.  In the meantime, maybe try to treat yourself like you would your best friend if she was going through this.  :)
Posts.Title: so tired of waiting... jsjherman jsjherman

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2014 04:05PM geekyknitter wrote: I've had more pain in my left breast than my right and sometimes they swap which is the worst. My mother also had fibroademas and back in that day and age, they always took them out with a lumpectomy.  I remember her dealing with drains and scarring and I'm rather glad that they are less eager to remove benign lumps and bumps than they used to be.  For now, they're just monitoring my fibroadema.  I have an appointment in 6 months to follow up on it with an ultrasound, just to be sure it's not growing and nothing else is going on.  I'd prefer to leave it alone as long as it isn't causing any trouble.
Posts.Title: Fibercystic Breast tissue-Left breast always causing me trouble. CCrill CCrill

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2014 08:57PM geekyknitter wrote: So glad that this biopsy went better!  Here's hoping for speedy results!! :)
Posts.Title: scared silly teaspoon teaspoon

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2014 07:54PM geekyknitter wrote: Oh...and as far as what comes after... For me, I scheduled the biopsy right after the ultrasound.  The radiologist was pretty sure it was a fibroadenoma, but wanted to be absolutely sure, so they set the appointment up for the next week.  The biopsy was pretty easy using just a large needle to take a core biopsy.  They numbed me completely before doing it and all you can see from it now (about a month after) is a tiny little nick of a scar.  Then, I had to wait about 4 days for my results.  With mine, we're just going to keep an eye on it to make sure it doesn't grow too much.  They generally only remove them now if they cause pain or keep growing.  Mine was marked with a titanium clip so that they can see it on future breast images. I was really anxious through the process, thinking through the whatif's, but beyond that, it wasn't painful and my imaging center was really good and making sure I understood each procedure.  I'm hoping yours will be just as simple!

Here's hoping you get benign results and FAST so that you can get back to your regularly scheduled programming!  :)

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2014 05:57PM geekyknitter wrote: Big, big hugs!  Waiting is hard, but hopefully they'll have your results soon.  Here, biopsy results typically take 5-7 business days, so, as tough as it might be, I'd try not to read too much into the results taking a little bit. Hugs!
Posts.Title: Still waiting... Lovemyboysandlabs ldyblu77

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2014 07:48PM geekyknitter wrote: Fibroadenomas are bengin and pretty common, particularly in younger women.  I have one myself and named him Brutus (yes, I have that kind of sense of humor!).  I ended up having a biopsy, which wasn't painful and pretty easy, which let us know exactly what Brutus was made of. It sounds like your doctors are doing everything right and sending you for an ultrasound.  The ultrasound will help them make sure it's not a cyst since cysts look different than fibroadenomas on imaging.  Then, if they can't completely rule anything out or just want to be really thorough, they can do a biopsy, using the ultrasound to guide it, if needed.  For me, the biopsy was another appointment and more waiting between.  :P  A fibroadenoma will look round or oval on the ultrasound screen, usually with nice, smooth edges. Good luck at your appointment and I hope you get benign results and quickly!
